messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using PHP and the Laravel 11.x (laravel/framework ^11.28) framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. In `app/Http/Controllers/PostLikeController.php`, I found that `App\\Http\\Controllers\\Api\\V1\\PostLikeController@destroy` is implemented to process HTTP requests. To determine the full path with the correct prefix and the acceptable HTTP methods, I found the necessary information in other files.

I'll provide you with the contents of all related files, and your task is to determine and output:

- The full HTTP request path for the endpoint, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}).
- Whether all HTTP methods are acceptable, this will override the results for other HTTP methods.
- Whether the HEAD method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the POST method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the OPTIONS method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the TRACE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the GET method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PUT method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the DELETE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PATCH method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.

You also need to provide an explanation of your results.

message.content:
- Full HTTP request path:
  /v1/posts/{post}/likes

- All HTTP methods acceptable: false

- HEAD: false

- POST: false

- OPTIONS: false

- TRACE: false

- GET: false

- PUT: false

- DELETE: true

- PATCH: false

Explanation:
- In routes/api.php the routes are grouped under Route::prefix('v1')->group(...). Inside that group the route registering the destroy action is:
  Route::delete('/posts/{post}/likes', [PostLikeController::class, 'destroy'])->name('posts.likes.destroy');
  Because of the prefix('v1') the full path is /v1/posts/{post}/likes and the route is explicitly registered with the HTTP DELETE method.
- The DELETE method is therefore the only method registered for this specific endpoint (App\Http\Controllers\Api\V1\PostLikeController@destroy). A separate POST route (Route::post('/posts/{post}/likes', [PostLikeController::class, 'store'])) exists for the store/action but that is a different route handler.
- The route definition does not register HEAD, OPTIONS, TRACE, GET, PUT, PATCH or a wildcard/all-methods route, so those methods are not acceptable for this endpoint according to the code (no assumptions about framework fallback behavior were made).
